name: Mujeres Unidas Group
use: to buy soda, wine, and beer amongst other drinks.
texts:
The group Mujeres Unidas (United Women) is a new group in it's first cycle where all members seek better conditions and believe that joining this committee would be great opportunity to achieve that goal.

One of the members is named Rosalina and through her effort and hard work in selling drinks, she has made a dignified and honest living. Rosalina strives to grow and to fight for her family so that they can move forward. She decided to join the committee to become better at what she does and to help support her home.

She requests this loan to buy soda, wine, and beer amongst other drinks which will help her create her business plan and improve her income.

name: Adama
use: to purchase more onions, palm oil, rice, sugar, gari, salt, rice, fish and other ingredients.
texts:
Greetings from Sierra Leone.

This is 22-year-old Adama from Blama road branch. She is married with two children aged between 3 and 6 years old. She started her business because she wants to take care of her family's welfare.

Adama has a table at a busy marketplace from where she sells onions, palm oil, rice, sugar, gari, tomato, salt, rice, fish, and other ingredients. These are bought by her customers to make local spicy stews (such as “green”, “cassava leaf”, “groundnut soup”, “pepper soup”, etc).

She has been in this business for 6 years now. She works 8 hours per day, 6 days a week. The main challenge to her business is transportation of goods.

Adama requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more onions, palm oil, rice, sugar, gari, salt, rice, fish, and other ingredients. Adama says that the extra income from this loan will help to take care of her family and educate her children.

Adama would like to see her business to grow in the future. She thanks you for your support.

name: Isma'ila
use: to purchase higher-yielding seeds and other farm inputs that will increase his crop yield.
texts:
Isma'ila, who resides in the village of Dalawa, is a Babban Gona maize farmer. He manages a 0.4-hectare maize farm, through which he supports his family.

Luckily, as a Babban Gona member, Isma'ila will, because of this loan, be provided with higher yielding seeds that are locally adapted, and are widely accepted in his local community. He will also have the recommended pesticides and fertilizers based on the results of his field assessment. This will enable him to optimize his yield, where he can attain yields of up to 3.8 metric tonnes per hectare, which is twice the national average in Nigeria. This will not only increase his income earnings 2.8 times the national average, but also will ensure that Isma'ila can continue to provide for his family.

Isma'ila will use the income generated from his maize sales this season to buy more farm land.

Reflecting on Isma'ila’s greatest memory as a Babban Gona farmer, a smile lights up his face as he remembers sending his children to better schools. Isma'ila is confident that with Babban Gona, his future is secure and that he will have many more great memories and amazing accomplishments.

name: Rehab
use: to buy grocery products, such as rice, flour, oil, cheese and sweets.
texts:
Rehab is 23, married, and has two children. She has small grocery store business and her husband works for the government.

She is requesting this loan to buy grocery products, such as rice, flour, oil, cheese and sweets, in order to expand the business and increase her sales during Ramadan and feast seasons, and increase her income.

name: Elizabeth
use: to buy farm supplies and seeds in order to have a bumper harvest and be able to expand her farm.
texts:
Elizabeth is a hardworking farmer from a remote village in the Kitale area of Kenya. Thanks to her daily efforts, she was able to give her children a good foundation by providing them with a good quality education.

Elizabeth has a farm where she grows crops and raises livestock; she also earns some income from a personal business. She never had a formal education and is content with the farming lifestyle.

Although Elizabeth has been making profits through farming, not everything has been easy for this humble and industrious mother. Her farm has not been producing as much of a harvest lately, due to a lack of fertilizer and good seeds and the presence of pests and diseases. That is why she is seeking a loan to buy farm supplies and seeds, so as to expand her horticulture farm.

With this loan, Elizabeth will be assured of a bumper harvest which will mean more profits and income. Using this loan, she will be able to expand her farming enterprise.

Elizabeth hopes you will consider her appeal for the loan; it would mean a lot to her and her family.

name: Sergey
use: to pay for special brushes and an easel, and repair his workshop.
texts:
Get to know another creative Armenian. This is Sergey, 39. Sergey is fully into arts. He is so good at different crafts like paintings, cross making crafts, sculpturing, etc. He works in a workshop near his apartment and there he receives different orders from local businesses and souvenir shops. Thanks to his passion towards crafts, Sergey supports his wife Gayane. Unfortunately, they are childless.

Now, Sergey has applied for this loan to pay for special brushes and an easel, and repair his workshop. This loan will allow him to take his business to the next level and have an enhanced workshop.

name: Emily
use: to buy seeds and start farming so that she can provide a better life for her three children.
texts:
This is Emily, a humble woman who lives in Kitale, Kenya, a post-conflict area where there is a high rate of poverty and unemployment. Despite these challenges, Emily is working hard to lift herself out of that dismal condition.

She is a very hardworking person. Thanks to her daily effort, she has managed to give her children a good start by providing them with a good quality education.

Emily’s primary sources of income are crops and animal farming. She also earns some income from a personal business. She never had a formal education, and is content with the farming lifestyle.

The Kitale area is a favorable area for farming, so she is seeking a loan to buy seeds to enable her to grow more vegetables and reap maximum profits and also increase her business.

Being a woman and accessing funds in Kenya, especially the Kitale area, is very challenging, but Emily feels relieved knowing there are institutions such as Kiva that help enterprising women like her. Her goal is to improve her living conditions and secure the future of her children.

Her biggest dreams are to be able to support her family by herself, to become independent and to buy a home.

name: Anju
use: to buy grocery goods for her store.
texts:
Anju is 35 years old. Many years ago, she established her grocery shop business. She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Patan BPW. She is using her most recent loan to buy grocery goods.

In the future, she plans to improve her family's economic condition. She thanks you for your support.

name: Suzan
use: to purchase more dried fish to increase her business.
texts:
Greetings from Sierra Leone.

This is 28-year-old Suzan from the Blama road branch. She is married with two children. She started her business because she wants to improve the standard of living of her family.

Suzan sells dried and smoked fish to her customers from a table near a busy market place. The fish is smoked on a grate whilst small pieces of wood burn underneath. Certain fish smokes better than others and Suzan tries to run her business in tune with local demand and whatever fish is available from the ports.

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more dried fish to increase her business. Suzan says that the extra income from this loan will help to repay her loan and to take care of her family. In the future, she would like to open a big fishing company. She thanks BRAC and Kiva for their support.

name: Rabie
use: to buy wood.
texts: Rabie is 38, married, and has one son. He is financially responsible for his aging mother and works as a constructions carpenter. He requested a loan before and fully repaid it on the due dates and is requesting this loan to buy wood to meet the demands of his customers.

name: Bakhtiyor
use: to pay for his wife’s treatment at the medical clinic.
texts:
Bakhtiyor is a kind man. He was born in 1984 into a laborer's family. He is clever and always tries to secure the well-being of his family. He is married and has three sons.

Bakhtiyor works at the school. He gets a salary. He does his job well and he is capable. He earns a low income and lives modestly.

Bakhtiyor needs financial support now because his wife is ill. He loves his wife and takes care of her by himself. He must buy medicine for her but his low salary is not enough to have his wife treated at a medical clinic.

Bakhtiyor is asking for a loan of 1200 TJS, which he will use to buy medicine for his wife’s treatment. He is a returning client and has a positive credit history. He is asking for a loan for the third time through Kiva's field partner, IMON. He awaits your mercy.

name: Gladys
use: to buy quality breeds of poultry.
texts:
Gladys is a smallholder farmer from a remote village in Eldoret in the Great Rift Valley area of Kenya. She resides with her husband and family. She has been actively involved in farming for the last five years and has never regretted it or looked back. She practices mixed farming and sells milk, eggs, and various food crops at the local market. Gladys passionately loves poultry farming, but the biggest challenge she faces is a lack of capital to buy quality breeds of poultry that are resistant to diseases and lay more eggs.

Gladys is seeking a loan to purchase additional poultry. She will use her excess maize to feed the poultry and will provide sorghum to give the poultry energy. Through better feeding, the birds will increase their egg production and will lay more eggs that are of good quality, which will translate to more income. Apart from an increase in egg production, she will get increased output from poultry meat, and this will further increase her income and profit margins.

Through increased profits, she intends to turn around her living conditions and live a better life. In addition to profits, Gladys will benefit from chicken manure, which contains the highest amount of nitrogen of any livestock manure and is very valuable as fertilizer. She will be able to save money that would have been spent to buy fertilizer.

Thanks to your support, Gladys will succeed in making her dreams come true; take action and make a loan!

name: Pauline
use: to buy seeds, fertilizer, and pesticides.
texts:
Pauline is a sweet woman, 48 years of age, and a veteran with great dreams to accomplish. Living in a poor country where work opportunities are scarce has never been an excuse for Pauline, who has been practicing mixed farming for the past 10 years.

Pauline is a woman eager to get ahead. She lives with her husband in the Kapsowar area of Kenya. She is blessed with a lovely family who are her greatest motivation in life. She perseveres because she wants to provide a better future for them.

Pauline has always had an affinity for farming and even nicknamed one of her cows. She is a very proud farmer and enjoys milking her dairy cows. Her cows produce between 8-10 liters a day and this helps her support her family. Pauline grows crops but she has not been making good profits because of poor farming inputs.

Pauline will use the loan to buy farm inputs. She wants to purchase high quality seeds, good fertilizer, and pesticides to improve crop production. Modern farming requires the use of modern techniques, and she believes that using high-quality seeds will assure her of a bumper harvest and increased profit levels.

Pauline is visionary, and her goal for the season is to boost her crop production over the previous year and also to build a modern house. All this can be achieved through lenders’ help and goodwill.

This loan will play a great role in pulling Pauline out of poverty.

name: Jenneh
use: to buy more cold water, drinks and soft drinks to sell.
texts:
Meet 29-year-old Jenneh. She is single with 2 children, aged 9 and 12 years old. Both of her children are in school and live at home.

Jenneh is involved in a business which sells cold water, drinks, and soft drinks. She sells 14 hours each day. She has operated this business for the past eight years.

She asked for a loan from BRAC Liberia, and says that the loan will be used to buy more cold water, drinks, and soft drinks to sell.

She sells in a shop. She received financial help from her friend, and her mother taught her the trade. She is proud of her business because it makes her an independent woman. Jenneh has had no problems with her business.

In the future, she would like to build and educate her children. She says a big thanks to all funders.

name: Mavjudahon
use: to purchase construction materials to renovate her house and provide a better living conditions for her family.
texts:
Mavjudahon has her own business in Balkhi She has a small shop where she sells food and household goods. Mavjudahon has been doing this for 10 years. She has two children, a son who is 12 and a daughter who is 18.

Mavjudahon is requesting a loan to purchase building materials to repair the house.

name: Kabita
use: to buy chickens and goats.
texts: Kabita is 39 years-old. In 2006, she established her meat shop business. She has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent one to buy chickens for her shop. In the future, she plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

name: Mohan Maya
use: to buy raw thread and wools.
texts:
Mohan Maya is 43 years old. In 2005, she started a carpet weaving business.

She has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Patan BPW, and used her most recent one to buy thread and wools for her business.

In the future, she plans to uplift the economic condition of her family.

She thanks you for your support.

name: Kanchi
use: to buy seeds and fertilizers.
texts: Kanchi is 52 years old. In 2003, she established her agriculture business. She has already received and successfully repaid three loans from Patan BPW, and she used her most recent loan to buy fertilizers and seeds. In the future, she plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

name: Isah
use: to purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his farm yield.
texts:
Isah, who resides in Yalwa village, is a Babban Gona maize farmer who manages a 1.5-hectare maize farm, through which he supports his family.

Luckily, as a Babban Gona member, Isah will because of this loan, be provided with higher yielding seeds that are locally adapted, and are widely accepted in his local community. He will also have the recommended pesticides and fertilizers based on the results of his field assessment. This will enable him to optimize his yield, where he can attain yields of up to 3.8 metric tonnes per hectare; 2 times the national average in Nigeria. This will not only increase his income earnings 2.8 times the national average but also ensure that Isah can continue to provide for his family. Isah will use the income generated from his maize sales this season to pay his children's school fees and also build a better house for his family.

Reflecting on Isah’s greatest memory as a Babban Gona farmer, a smile lights up his face as he remembers buying more farmlands. Isah is confident that with Babban Gona, his future is secure and that he will have many more great memories and amazing accomplishments.

name: Isiya
use: to purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farm yield.
texts:
Isiya, a Babban Gona maize farmer, is married and lives in a modest cement house with his family in Dan-daura village. Isiya is a meticulous farmer who has invested time and resources on his farm, and like every parent, hopes to send his children to good schools.

Thanks to the previous loans that he got from Kiva, he registered six of his children in better schools.

He decided to apply for another loan to have access to high quality seeds that are locally adapted, and widely accepted in his local community. He will also have the recommended pesticides and fertilizer based on the results of his field assessment. This will enable him to optimize his yield, where he can attain yields of up to 3.8 metric tonnes per hectare; 2 times the national average in Nigeria. This will not only increase his income earnings 2.8 times the national average, but also ensures that Isiya can continue to provide for his family.

Isiya looks forward to using his additional income to pay his children's school fees, and recalls gaining a better yield as his best memory as a Babban Gona member.

Isiya looks forward to a brighter future with Babban Gona, as he, too, has joined the fight against poverty.

name: Adaly
use: to buy a 100-watt solar energy system, 6 lights, a 16-inch television, a DVD player, and accessories to be installed in his home.
texts:
Sr. Adaly is married and has one son. He currently makes a living growing basic grains, especially corn and sorghum. There is no electricity in the community where he lives. For this reason, he is requesting a loan to buy a solar energy system, which will be installed at his home and will be very useful to all the members of the household since they will have light without the need for candles and will be able to enjoy watching a little television together as a family.

Sr. Adaly and his family will be very grateful to receive this opportunity to purchase this solar energy system.

name: Monica Elizabeth
use: to buy merchandise such as: mirrors, lifting arms, and other things.
texts:
Monica lives in the city of Ibarra. She is 30 years old and lives with her husband and their 2 small children.
Monica has a family business selling vehicle supplies such as mirrors, windows, lifting arms, and other things. Meanwhile, her husband repairs the vehicles in a small workshop which they currently have.
Monica is requesting a loan to buy merchandise for her business so that she will have more income for the home.

name: Mary
use: to construct a modern cow shed.
texts:
The price of success is hard work and this applies to this hardworking woman, Mary. She uses the wheelbarrow shown in the picture above to carry animal feed, manure, and other farm supplies and inputs. Mary works every day on her farm, from Monday to Friday, so that she can be able to provide for her family, being the sole breadwinner.

Mary owns a small farm on the outskirts of Eldoret town in a humble village, which is situated in the Great Rift Valley of Kenya. The income she makes from farming is not sufficient to comfortably sustain her large family. As a result, Mary has ventured into a couple of small side businesses to make extra shillings. With the aid of her energetic husband, Mary also rears poultry and grows maize, among other crops.

Mary is seeking a loan of KES 20,000 for constructing a cowshed. To make good use of your loan, Mary has carefully planned for the storage and handling of milk, feed, bedding, and manure, as these account for most of the labor in any dairy farm. The cowshed will have a plentiful, dependable supply of good water made available 24 hours a day.

The income Mary will make from this investment will put her in a position to comfortably afford the increasing costs of farming. Her family also stands to benefit from the growth of their agribusiness. Support this heroine who wants to always put smiles on her large family's faces.

name: Catherine
use: to buy new farm tools and equipment.
texts:
Catherine has clear and realistic goals. She wants to provide her children with a decent lifestyle, to pay for their education, and to elevate the standards of living in her family.

Catherine is a smallholder farmer who has been involved in mixed farming for more than 10 years, and has gained a lot of knowledge, skills, and experience.

Catherine spends her day attending to her dairy cow and cultivating her land. However she has often times complained that working on her land has become tedious and tiresome. One factor contributing to this is the type of tools she employs.

Catherine is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase farm tools and equipment.

Smallholder farmers usually use indigenous tools because they are economical, feasible, and sustainable. Despite being common, they are generally not preferred to modern tools since they are inefficient and tiring to use.

Catherine will be able to afford modern tools. These tools will make her work easier and more efficient.

Money from this investment will go toward her family's basic expenses.

name: Shoista
use: to buy cattle to increase the number of cattle.
texts:
Shoista is a hardworking 50-year-old woman. She is married, and mother of several children; she also has grandchildren. She tries to support her family and always works tirelessly.

Shoista is engaged in animal husbandry. She began to deal with this business when she was young. This business gives a very good income. Shoista is very grateful to her children for their help.

In addition, she grows cucumbers and tomatoes.

At the moment, Shoista plans to buy livestock and increase the number of livestock.

For this reason, Shoista appealed to Arvand for a loan.

This is her first loan from Arvand and Kiva.

She awaits your mercy and generosity .

name: Edwin
use: to buy a 100 watt solar energy system, 6 spark plugs, and accessories to be installed in his house.
texts:
Edwin is married and has 2 children. At present, he is dedicated to growing coffee and basic grains. In the community where he lives, there is no electricity.

Because of this, he is requesting a loan to buy a solar energy system, which will be installed in his house. This will be a major benefit for all members of his household, since it will improve the ability to do farm work.

Edwin and his family would be very thankful if they are offered this opportunity to buy this system.

name: Rosa Victoria
use: to buy thread, fabric, and buttons, to make embroidered items for sale.
texts:
Rose lives in the city of Ibarra and is 41 years old. She is currently divorced and lives with her 3 children, 2 of whom are minors. Rosa has worked very hard to raise her family alone. She is an embroidery artisan, and can make any type of embroidery in different materials that can be used as blouses, blankets, and other things. She sells her products in the markets every weekend.
Rosa is requesting a loan to buy materials such as: thread, fabric, buttons, and other things as she has to deliver an order. This will enable her to save for the school season and to buy everything that her children need.

name: Blanca Alicia
use: to buy staple goods to sell in her store and to buy agricultural supplies.
texts:
Blanca studied until the 6th grade. She is married and her husband works on a farm.
Blanca has had a grocery store for some years. She decided to start the business because their wasn't any competition in the community. She also has experience in agriculture and raising domesticated animals.
She has had the support of 3 Kiva loans and has improved her life and finished her repayments. She needs a new loan to buy staple goods to sell in her store and she will buy agricultural supplies.
She hopes to always have her store and wants to improve her home.

name: Jessica Marinela
use: to buy notebooks, pencils, markers, paper, folders, etc, to supply her stationary store.
texts:
Jessica is studying at the higher level. She is single and lives with her parents.
She has had a small stationary store for more than 5 years and she learned this business from her grandma. The business is located in her home and she serves customers there.
She will use the loan to buy notebooks, pencils, markers, paper, folders, etc, to supply her stationary store.
Jessica dreams of being a professional in the future and expanding her store. She also hopes to start a family in some years time.

name: Jackline
use: to buy farm inputs such as seeds to improve her horticulture farming.
texts:
This is Jackline (pictured above in her humble house), a woman who is full of smiles. She is a person who has had to overcome a lot of adversity in her life. However, she has always had the strength to overcome it and move forward with her children. She is very hardworking and a go-getter. She hails from a remote village in the Kerugoya area of Kenya. Her primary sources of income are crops and animal farming. She also gets some income through personal business.

Jackline is a very enterprising woman. Although she never had formal education or formal employment, she has always worked hard on her farm and assured her children and family a decent meal. The Kerugoya area has favorable conditions for horticulture farming, and she is seeking a loan to buy farm inputs such as seeds to improve her horticulture farming. Because of good roads, a good climate, and a good transportation network, she is sure that she will reap maximum profits and be able to increase her business.

Being an older woman and accessing funds in Africa is very challenging, but Jackline feels relieved knowing there are institutions such as Kiva that help hardworking women like her.

As the month of June is starting, Jackline wants to start the month on a high note. Please help Jackline so that her horticulture farming can flourish!

name: Stella
use: to buy farm inputs.
texts:
“When small scale farmers are given access to credit, they are very hard working,” says Stella, a smallholder farmer of both crops and livestock. For the past five years, she has been actively involved, and making great profits, in farming.

Through her dairy cows, Stella is able to get between 8-10 litres a day and this helps her support her family. She also practices crop farming, but she has not been making good profits because of poor farming inputs. This is why she is kindly seeking a loan to buy farm inputs.

Through the loan, Stella will be able to buy high-quality seeds, good fertilizer and pesticides that she will use to greatly improve her crop production.

Modern farming requires the use of modern techniques. Using high-quality seeds will assure her of a bumper harvest and hence, increased profit levels.

Stella is a visionary, and her goal for the season is to boost her crop production and be able to get more crop output than the previous year.

Stella believes that through the loan, she will turn around her family life and be able to give her children a solid educational background.

This loan will surely have great impact on the well-being of Stella’s family.

name: Nance
use: to buy quality seeds, fertilizer, pesticides and herbicides.
texts:
Hello!

The nice woman in the picture is Nance. Nance, 48 years of age, is a very hardworking, progressive and honest farmer from a very remote village in the Litein area of Kenya.

This area is very fertile, with favorable weather patterns that support farming activities. Nance is happily married, and she is a proud mother. Together, they live on a small piece of land that she really treasures.

Her primary sources of income are eggs, milk and a variety of food crops that she grows on her farm.

Although this humble and industrious mother makes a profit, she faces the challenge of not being able to produce enough to meet the ready market that is available.

Therefore, she is seeking funds from Kiva lenders to buy farm inputs like good fertilizer, good quality seeds, herbicides and pesticides.

Through this loan, she will double her production and this will translate into increased income. She then intends to save more money in the future, so that she can develop her farming.

This loan will help Nance to realize her dream of getting out of poverty, and she will be able to secure her family's future.

name: Tamanno
use: to bring a range of summer fabrics to attract more customers to her point.
texts:
Tamanno is a single mother, age 35. She had one child when she got divorced. Now her child is already going to school, she does not receive any help from her ex-husband.

Tamanno hopes for her strength and capabilities. After the collapse of her marriage, she started her own business in order to provide herself and the child. Tamanno acquired a retail outlet in the market of her Shahritus region, and began to sell fabrics and materials. Her sister helps her in the business. She works hard for her child, because he is her only support and the meaning of life.

Tamanno now needs a loan. She wants to bring a range of summer fabrics to attract more customers to her point.

Your support is needed for her now.

name: Santos Mario
use: to buy thread to make hammocks and fertilizer for his crops.
texts:
Santos is 41 years old. He studied until 6th grade but, because of scarce economic resources, he could not continue his studies and decided when he was small to be a farmer. He has a partner who works making hammocks. They have 3 children, 2 of whom are in school.
Santos works in agriculture and he learned farming from his parents. He has his crops on the other side of the river. He also makes hammocks along with his partner and he has experience as a mason.
He needs a loan to buy thread for making hammocks and fertilizer for his crops.
Santos wants to grow his business and have a method of transportation for his crops.

name: Ana Del Carmen
use: to buy corn to sell tortillas.
texts:
Ana could only study until third grade in school. She has 3 children and is a single mother.

Ana has been dedicated to selling tortillas for more than 5 years. She started the business with her own money, and she sells in front of her house.

Ana needs help from a loan to buy corn to sell tortillas. She wants to go forward with her children and have a dignified life.

name: Ana Elsy
use: to buy agricultural supplies for growing corn and beans.
texts:
Ana is 60 years old. She is married and has 3 grown-up children. Her husband works in agriculture.
Ana has more than 21 years of experience working in agriculture. She grows corn and beans and she also works on the coffee farms.
She needs this loan to buy agricultural supplies to grow corn and beans. Her previous Kiva loan helped her to work and she repaid the debt punctually.
Ana dreams of starting a business selling ice-cream and having an extra source of income.

name: Esther
use: to buy more soap, garri, sugar, candy, biscuits, cream, grease and other items to sell.
texts:
TThis is 43-year-old Esther. She is a widow with six children ranging in age from 10 through 25. Esther went to school up to 3rd grade. Four of her children are in school and they live at home. Esther runs a business where she sells soap, garri, sugar, candy, biscuits, cream, grease and other items. She stated that her business is her only source of income. Being the only surviving parent, Esther sells from 6:00 am to 9:00 pm each day to meet their daily needs. She has been operating this business for 15 years.

To add to the business, she applied for a loan with BRAC Liberia. The loan will be used to buy more soap, garri, sugar, candy, biscuits, cream, grease and other items to sell and increase her income. She received financial help from her late husband to start her business and learned the trade from her grandmother. She describes herself as a hardworking business woman. Esther says when discussing her business that she feels so proud because it helps bring in support on a daily basic and she has lot of customers.

In the future, she would like to build houses and send her children to a better school. She says a big thanks to all funders.

name: Estela
use: buy children's clothing to sell to friends and neighbors.
texts:
Estela is 50 years old. She has lived in a rented home in the area of Pueblo Libre, Jaén, Perú for 10 years. Estela fills the role of mother and father for her daughters, who are now beyond her authority.

Currently, Estela works part time as a cleaning assistant at a private early education school. Thanks to her savings from work, she was able to start her business selling children's clothing.

She has had her small business selling children's clothing for 2 years. This has allowed her to move her family forwards and now her dream is to expand her business by using the loan to buy children's clothing.

This is her first loan from Norandino and she is thankful for the opportunity to show that she is a responsible woman.

name: Yolom Nere 14 Group
use: to purchase "pagnes" (traditional cloths) in gross and to sell them.
texts: Yolom Neré 14 just finished their first loan with Kiva.  The repayments were done normally.  Alimata, the representative member, thanks all of the personnel and the lenders at Kiva for their support.  With the loan Alimata was able to buy some "pagnes" (traditional cloths) and some ready to wear and to sell them.  She had a profit that allowed her to pay for outfits for her children, to make several expenditures for her family and most of all to expand her business.  Alimata again needs loans to continue her business in order to stock up her shop with new "pagnes" (traditional cloths) to please her customers and therefore to have good sales and to flourish more.

name: Risper
use: to purchase more stock of assorted fruits and vegetables for sale.
texts:
Risper is 29 years old, married, and blessed with three children. She has been in business for two and half years.

Risper will use her loan to purchase more stock of assorted fruits and vegetables for sale to improve her business. She will use her income to educate her children and improve their living standard.

name: Lydiah
use: to buy farm inputs.
texts:
Lydiah is the mother of three children and is a rural smallholder farmer from the Riokindo, Kenyenya area of Kenya. Lydiah is married to a fellow farmer. Her family's main income source is from selling milk from their dairy farm. However, they are also involved in other agricultural activities such as growing bananas, vegetables, fruits, and grains.

The biggest problem that farmers from Riokindo face is the huge deficit in terms of access to agricultural inputs, meaning that farmers' yields and incomes are far below what they could be. Juhudi Kilimo partnered with Kiva to provide financial services to smallholders around Kenya. Through these financial services, farmers from Riokindo, Kenyenya, like Lydiah, can now buy productive assets and important agricultural inputs for use on their farms.

Lydiah is seeking a loan to buy farm inputs such as seeds, fertilizer, herbicides, and pesticides. Your loan will enable her to improve her production through the use of quality farm inputs. This intervention will help her fill the increasing demand for food in the market and, in the process, generate more income to repay the loan debt and improve the quality of life for her family. She hopes to improve the conditions in her house.

Help this mother to accomplish all her dreams with just a loan!

name: Víctor Manuel
use: to buy various types of cell phone equipment and accessories.
texts:
Víctor is a cell phone maintenance and repair technician. He lives in Bosa, which is a town in the municipality of Bogotá. He offers services and also sells cell phone equipment and accessories. He has spent 15 years in this business, and the results have been better than he hoped. His clients are very satisfied with his services and have referred him to others. Because of this, he has succeeded in increasing his clientele.

His goal for the future is to grow his business. At present, he is in the process of getting his first Kiva loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo to buy various types of cell phone equipment and accessories. In this way, he will be able to offer various product lines. Víctor wants to continue growing and to have doors open with the loan. Support this small business.

name: Mohbi
use: to buy a computerized sewing machine to sew a greater variety of dresses for her customers to wear to attend different events.
texts:
Mohbi is very satisfied with the first loan she received. She was able to pay for her daughter's medical treatment with the loan. Thanks to your support, dear creditors, my daughter has recovered, says Mohbi. She is the happiest mom.

Mohbi now enjoys her sewing business and needs to buy a new modernized sewing machine. Mohbi wants to expand her sewing activities and attract more customers. She is sure that this time you will not ignore her. Mohbi thanks you.

name: Rafode Limited
use: to buy Jikokoa stoves to sell.
texts:
The borrower has been going from strength to strength and now wants to also stock the new wood burning life saving stoves, as well as the original charcoal.

Rafode Limited is a successful distributor of the Jikokoa products. The person in the photo is a sales agent for Rafode Limited.

name: Sophia
use: to buy poultry so that she can increase her business to meet high demand for poultry products.
texts:
Sophia is a woman who is very dedicated to her work. She works tirelessly every day of the week, from Monday to Sunday. She lives in Eldoret, a remote town in Kenya. She is happily married and blessed with lovely children.

She has been practicing mixed farming for the past five years and has gained a great deal of experience. To afford a decent and comfortable life for her children, she has been selling milk, eggs, and a variety of food crops from her farm.

The Eldoret area is very populated, and the demand for poultry products and eggs is very high. Like many farmers from her region, she finds poultry farming very enjoyable. She stated that the best part about poultry farming is “the increased profits I enjoy.” Her biggest challenge, however, is meeting demand, which is really high.

She lacks funds to increase her poultry farming business, and she is seeking a loan of 20,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) to buy poultry.

To buy poultry, Sophia needs the trust and understanding of lenders. She really counts on your support now and in the future.

name: Leah
use: to buy farm inputs and hire laborers so that she can grow more crops on her horticulture farm.
texts:
Dear Kiva lender! Meet Leah, a smallholder farmer from a remote village in the Kerugoya area of Kenya. She started farming five years ago on a small plot she acquired. On the farm, she has dairy cows and a small garden.

Leah is seeking a 60,000 KES loan, which she will use to pay for farm inputs and to hire labor to grow more crops on the farm. It takes a lot for a smallholder farmer to risk limited resources to expand a farm business.

With your help, Leah will be able to pay the high cost of farm inputs necessary for expansion. A significant portion of the profits will be plowed back into the business to fuel growth as she sets a good foundation for her children. She really hopes for your help and contribution. Leah is thankful in advance.

name: Emily
use: to buy farm inputs.
texts:
Emily is the mother of one child and is a rural smallholder farmer from the Ndogo, Chuka area of Kenya. Emily is married to a fellow farmer. Her family's main income source is from selling milk from their dairy farm. However, they are involved in other agricultural activities such as growing bananas, vegetables, fruits, and grains.

The biggest problem that farmers from Ndogo face is the huge deficit in access to agricultural inputs, meaning that farmer yields and incomes are far below what they could be. Juhudi Kilimo partnered with Kiva to provide financial services to smallholder farmers around Kenya. Through these financial services, farmers from Ndogo, Chuka, like Emily, now can buy productive assets and important agricultural inputs for use on their farms.

Emily is seeking a loan to buy farm inputs such as seeds, fertilizer, herbicides, and pesticides. Your loan will enable her to improve her production through the use of quality farm inputs. This intervention will help her fill the increasing demand for food in the market and, in the process, generate more income to repay the loan debt and improve the quality of life for her family. Emily hopes to improve the conditions in her house.

Help this mother to accomplish all her dreams with just a loan!

name: Shokhrukh
use: to pay for his tuition at the National University of Tajikistan.
texts:
The man in this photo is Shokhrukh. He was born in 1994 into a family of workers, and is unmarried. He is a very kind and responsible man who is bright and well bred. He studies hard and has excellent marks. He participates in a lot of social circles.

Shokhrukh is studying at the faculty of Economy at the National University of Tajikistan. The university is asking him to pay the tuition fees for his studies, but his parents have a small income and only have a little money, so it is hard for them to pay his university tuition.

Shokhrukh is requesting a 2,000 TJS loan to pay his university tuition. He hopes that with your help and understanding, he will be able to pay and continue to study.

name: Ibrahim
use: to purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his farm yield.
texts:
Ibrahim who resides in Barbaji village is a Babban Gona maize farmer who manages a 0.4-hectare maize farm, through which he supports his family.

Luckily, as a Babban Gona member, Ibrahim will because of this loan, be provided with higher yielding seeds that are locally adapted, and are widely accepted in his local community. He will also have the recommended pesticides and fertilizers based on the results of his field assessment. This will enable him to optimize his yield, where he can attain yields of up to 3.8 metric tonnes per hectare, 2 times the national average in Nigeria. This will not only increase his income earnings 2.8 times the national average but also ensures that Ibrahim can continue to provide for his family.

Ibrahim will use the income generated from his maize sales this season to buy more farmlands. Reflecting on Ibrahim’s greatest memory as a Babban Gona farmer, a smile lights up his face as he remembers gaining better yields as a Babban Gona member. Ibrahim is confident that with Babban Gona, his future is secured and that he will have many more great memories and amazing accomplishments.

name: Anteh We 2 Group
use: to buy more kids wear, plates and plastic bowls.
texts:
Patience is a 35-year-old woman who is in a blue-black dress on the left side of the photo.

Patience has owned a retail business for the past seven years. Like many of those in the group, her business is well-organized.

Despite the hard times, Patience is determined to operate a successful business in order to provide a better life for her family. Patience has requested a loan from Kiva through ID-Ghana in order to buy more kids wear, plates and plastic bowls.

With the profits from this loan, she will be able to reinvest in her business.

Other members of the group own different businesses; some sell foodstuffs, groceries and roasted fishes.

name: Inusa
use: to purchase improved farm inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, that will increase his crop yield.
texts:
Inusa is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Kara, and he resides with his family in a mud house. Inusa manages a 0.3-hectare maize farm, through which he supports his family.

Thanks to his hard work, Inusa and his family can have three square meals a day. Because he’s a Babban Gona member, this loan will provide him with higher yielding seeds that are locally adapted, and are widely accepted in his local community. He will also have the recommended pesticides and fertilizers based on the results of his field assessment. This will enable Inusa to optimize his yield, where he can attain yields of up to 3.8 metric tonnes per hectare: two times the national average in Nigeria. This will not only increase his income earnings 2.8 times the national average, but will also ensure that Inusa can continue to provide for his family.

This season, Inusa hopes to to be the best performing farmer in his community, and recalls sending his children to better schools as his greatest memory as a Babban Gona farmer. Inusa is confident that with Babban Gona, his future is secure and that he will have many more great memories and amazing accomplishments together with his family.

name: Hassen
use: to purchase new merchandise for the grocery store like sugar, bread flour, broad beans, and soft drinks.
texts:
Hassen would like first to thank all Kiva lenders who helped him in his previous loan to purchase goods for his store. That loan helped him in meeting the demand of his clients.

Due to the ongoing conflict for more than two years, Hassen's business has been affected very much because he spends most what he earns from the store in covering the expenses of his family, as he has not received his monthly salary from the government for more than seven months. Now, his only income source is the grocery store.

Hassen is not able to purchase new merchandise and meet the demand of his clients as he doesn't have enough money. To solve this problem, he has applied for a 200,000 YER loan from Al-Amal Microfinance Bank to purchase new merchandise like sugar, bread flour, broad beans, and soft drinks. This would help him in meeting the demand of his clients and increase his profit.

Hassen is looking forward to expanding his business after the end of the current conflict.

name: Isa
use: to purchase improved farm inputs, like higher-yielding seeds, that will increase his crop yield.
texts:
Isa, a Babban Gona maize farmer from the village of Hago, has been a Babban Gona farmer for two seasons. He has one child who aspires to be a farmer in the future.

Previously, Isa and his family were able to eat only two meals a day, despite toiling for several hours on the farm. However, as a Babban Gona member, he will, as a result of this loan, be provided with higher-yielding seeds that are locally adapted, and are widely accepted in his local community. He will also have the recommended pesticides and fertilizers based on the results of his field assessment. This will enable him to optimize his yield, where he can attain yields of up to 3.8 metric tonnes per hectare, which is twice the national average in Nigeria

This season, Isa will use the income generated from his maize sales to buy more farmland.

Isa’s greatest memory as a Babban Gona farmer was when he sent his child to a better school as a result of the loan he got in the past. Isa is confident that with Babban Gona, his future is secure and that he will have many more great memories and amazing accomplishments together with his family.

name: Madhu
use: to buy grocery goods to sell.
texts: Madhu is 37 years old. In 2007, she established her grocery business. She has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Patan BPW. She used her most recent loan to buy grocery goods for her business. In the future, she plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

name: Tania Andriamanantenasoa
use: to purchase 50 kg of beef and 30 kg of giblets.
texts: 26 years old, Tania is married.  Her spouse supports her in the procurement.  Together, the couple has a child already in school.  Tania has had a butcher shop since 2013.  It is the principle source of income for the household.  The market is solid but it is necessary to have at one's disposal sufficient quantity of meat for the business to be profitable.  The profitability of the business depends as well on the diversification of products offered to customers.  This third loan will allow her to increase the quantity of meat offered to customers and to purchase giblets.  The goal of the couple is to create another point of sale.

name: Shehnaz
use: to purchase nutrition-rich fodder for the buffaloes, in order to increase milk production.
texts:
Shehnaz is a woman of 48 years who lives with her family in a small village. She owns a few buffaloes and sells their milk in town to earn a living. She has been following old and traditional ways of managing buffaloes, resulting in gradual decrease in production of milk. She and her husband consulted a local veterinary officer and he recommended getting nutrition-rich fodder for the buffaloes to improve their milk production.

She therefore has applied for a loan to purchase nutrition-rich fodder for the buffaloes. She is hopeful that this will be helpful in increasing milk production.

She is thankful to Kiva and JWS Pakistan.

name: Suriya
use: to buy materials such as leather petals, wax, thread and protective gloves for football making.
texts:
Suriya is a 47-year-old married woman who lives in the remote area of Sheikhupura City, Pakistan. She has been stitching and selling handmade footballs to earn her livelihood for the past two years.

Currently, due to a lack of money, Suriya is unable to purchase the required raw materials such as leather petals, wax, thread and protective gloves. She therefore has applied for a loan from Kiva’s field partner JWS Pakistan. She hopes that the loan amount will be useful for her business.

Suriya is very happy and thanks Kiva lenders for this opportunity.

name: Tien's Group
use: to build a cow cage in order to improve her cow-raising business to grow well.
texts:
Originally from Takeo province, Tien is 57 years old and married with three children. Because of her familly's condition, she can earn income via catching fish and cow-raising to get extra income. She has been involved with her current businesses for 32 years and it has helped her to save from the daily income about 5 USD per day for future needs.

For Tien, this is her ninth loan with VisionFund and she already paid her past loans back on time. Her living condition has improved via the previous loans. Now, she is leading a group of two members to seek this new loan. As the leader, she will use her entire loan to build a cow cage to take care of her cows well. She wishes that this loan will help her family’s business run smooth and gain more income to update her standard of living.

name: Ruzanna
use: to pay for four baby bulls in order to expand the livestock.
texts:
Ruzanna is a positive and energetic woman from Noravan village. She is 46 and lives with her son, Michael, 21. Ruzanna is widowed; however, she is a true survivor and concentrates only on optimism.

Ruzanna works at a local office as a cleaner. She also runs a prosperous farm. Ruzanna keeps cows, sheep, and lambs, as well as growing potatoes, wheat, and beech. Through agri-production sales, she wins daily bread for her little family.

Now she has applied for this loan to pay for four baby bulls in order to expand the livestock. This loan will allow Ruzanna to have a more profitable farm and organized household.

name: Idris
use: to purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farm yield.
texts:
Idris resides in Zuntu village and is a Babban Gona maize farmer who manages a 1-hectare maize farm, through which he supports his family.

Luckily, as a Babban Gona member and because of this loan, Idris will be provided with higher yielding seeds that are locally adapted and widely accepted in his local community. He will also have the recommended pesticides and fertilizers based on the results of his field assessment. This will enable him to optimize his yield, where he can attain yields of up to 3.8 metric tonnes per hectare; 2 times the national average in Nigeria. This will not only increase his income to 2.8 times the national average but also ensures that Idris can continue to provide for his family.

Idris will use the income generated from his maize sales this season to pay his children's school fees. Reflecting on Idris’s greatest memory as a Babban Gona farmer, a smile lights up his face as he remembers sending his children to better schools. Idris is confident that with Babban Gona, his future is secured and he will have many more great memories and amazing accomplishments.

name: Ilhom
use: to buy cattle to increase the size of his herd.
texts:
Ilhom, age 26, studied until he received his undergraduate degree. He is married and lives with his wife and several children.

He is a farmer. He learned this endeavor from his parents. At the beginning, he started his business at his parent's house. Since moving to another house, he farms with his family. Besides animal breeding, he also earns a profit from building and renovating people's houses. Currently he is renovating his own house, too.

Ilhom wants to increase the number of livestock to fatten and resell later, and increase his profits, which he wants to use to finish his home renovations. Since Ilhom lacks money, he appealed to Arvand for a new loan. He hopes for your mercy and generosity.

name: Margaret
use: to buy farm inputs, such as fertilizer and seeds, to help her grow more vegetables.
texts:
Greetings from Kitale, Kenya!

Margaret is a hardworking farmer from a remote village in the Kitale area of Kenya. Thanks to her daily efforts, she has managed to give her children a good start by providing them with a good-quality education.

Margaret has a farm where she grows crops and raises livestock. She also earns additional income from a personal business. She has never had a formal education and is content with the farming lifestyle.

The Kitale area is a favorable one for farming, so she is seeking a 50,000 KES loan through Kiva's field partner, Juhudi Kilimo, to buy farm inputs, such as fertilizer and seeds, to enable her to grow more vegetables, reap maximum profits, and increase her business.

Being a woman and accessing funds in Kenya, especially around Kitale, is very challenging, but Margaret feels relieved knowing there are institutions such as Kiva that help enterprising women like herself. She always works to improve her family’s living conditions, but her biggest dreams are to become independent and support her family by herself, to secure her children’s future, and to buy a home.

Margaret is confident that with the help of wonderful Kiva lenders, she will overcome poverty, securing a strong future for generations to come.

name: Fatuma
use: to buy more stock of vegetables to sell.
texts:
Fatuma is a married woman. She has two children.

She operates a retail business where she sells vegetables. She has been involved in this business for ten years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

She will use the 25,000 KES loan to buy more stock of vegetables. She hopes that in the future, she will be successful. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the anticipated profits to purchase more vegetables for her business.

name: Joseph
use: to buy more stock of farm tools and utensils to sell.
texts:
Joseph is a married man. He has four children. He operates a retail business where he sells utensils and farm tools. He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located in a good area, and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

He will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of farm tools and utensils. He hopes that in the future, he will be successful.

This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

name: Rosalia
use: to buy blocks, cement, gravel, steel bars, lumber, GI sheets, a toilet bowl, tiles, tire wire, pipe, and solvent.
texts:
Rosalia is a 62-year-old widow from the community of Ubay in the province of Bohol, Philippines. She is engaged in selling affordable clothing in her place such as dresses, shorts, shirts, skirts and blouses. She has three dependents aged 8-12.

She is asking for a loan to renovate her toilet. She will use her loan to buy blocks, cement, gravel, steel bars, lumber, GI sheets, a toilet bowl, tiles, tire wire, pipe, and solvent. This kind of loan is beneficial to her family because this will make their life more comfortable.

name: Zikabi
use: to purchase a combine harvester.
texts:
Zikabi is one of the hardworking and responsible residents of the city of Sarband. She is 46 years old, and in her city she is a respected woman. She always helps people in need. Zikabi has 6 children, who are all married and very well-educated. Her older son is engaged in agriculture and the youngest sells meat in the market.

For 10 years, Zikabi has been engaged in agriculture. In order to have a good life, she works day and night. Soon the irrigation season will open in Tajikistan, and to make her work easier Zikabi wants to buy a modern сombine harvester for her husband. As the сombine harvester is expensive, she needs to take out a loan. With this loan her husband will be able to increase their business and develop the city's agriculture.

name: Hokimoi
use: to buy groceries to sell in her store.
texts:
Hokimoi is 56 years old. She is a hardworking woman with a great desire to get ahead. She is married and has children.

Hokimoi sells a variety of grocery products. She acquires her products in shopping centers in the city. She makes periodic trips to accomplish her goal. She began working this way over 16 years ago because she needed to earn money. Currently, she needs help to purchase merchandise for her own business.

Hokimoi is asking for a loan for the first time from Kiva's field partner IMON. With this loan, she aims to expand her business in order to increase her working capital. She promises to pay back her loan on time. She is grateful for the financial support, which will help her to realize her plans. She awaits your support.

name: Isabelle Paquerette
use: to purchase fabric and various accessories for the clothing business.
texts: 49 years old, Isabelle is married and the mother of two children who are in school.  For a source of income, Isabelle has a small clothing business, created in 2011.  She has enough experience in this area because of her 10 years in a textile company.  The profitability of the clothing business depends on the number of clothes made therefore the need to build up a sufficient stock of fabric and various accessories for the consistency of production.  She also does special order work.  The goal is to have her own house to avoid paying rent.

name: Shamim
use: to buy stitching inputs like cloths, colorful threads, needles, buttons and laces.
texts:
Shamim is a woman entrepreneur who is struggling to bring prosperity to her family. She is 41 years old and lives in a small house with 6 family members. She is a skilled woman and has adopted cloth stitching as a source of livelihood. She has around 4 years of experience in cloth designing and stitching.

She works at her home and provides tailoring services to the women of her community. Her stitching quality has earned her a good fame within just a few years of services. She is very eager and wants to promote her business more over time.

At the moment she is lacking finances to purchase raw material including cloths, colorful threads, needles, buttons and laces for cloth stitching. She therefore has requested loan from JWS Pakistan, field partner of Kiva, to finance the raw material for her business.

Shamim is very thankful to Kiva and JWS Pakistan.

name: Sat
use: to buy more cows to expand her business.

location.town: Prey Veng Province, Peam Ror District

texts:
Sat is 37 years old and married with one child. They are living in a rural area of Prey Veng province. The main sources of her family’s income are from growing rice and raising cows, which she has been doing for many years.

With her businesses, she is able to save 3 USD per day. Her family's business challenge has been selling rice at the lowest price on the market. For Sat, this is her second loan cycle with VisionFund. She has managed her past loan wisely to improve her living condition and she has fully repaid her past loan on time.

Sat will use her loan to buy more cows to support her in expanding her business. She hopes this loan can help her family’s business grow well and earn more income to update her lifestyle better in the future.

name: Hellen
use: to purchase additional stock of clothing for resale so that she can raise funds to educate her children.
texts:
Hellen is 49 years old. She is married with two children.

She has had a clothing business for three years.

She will be using the loan to purchase additional stock of clothing for resale so that she can raise funds to educate her children.

With the anticipated income, Hellen will repay her loan.

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to educate her children until university.

name: Violetta
use: to pay her school tuition fee so she can graduate from the university.
texts:
Meet Violetta! This nice girl is 20 years old. Violetta is from the town of Kapan, where she lives with her mother and younger sister. Violetta's mother makes and sells cakes and her sister is a student.

Violetta studies at European Regional Academy, in the IT department. She studies happily and tries her best. However, Violetta's family income is not enough to pay for her higher education expenses. Violetta has kindly asked for this loan to pay her school tuition fee so she can graduate from the university.

This loan will truly have an enormous impact for Violetta.

name: Sabohat
use: to pay for her treatment at the medical clinic.
texts:
The woman in this photo is Sabohat, a very kind and responsible woman. She was born in 1971, is married, and has two sons, a daughter-in-law and a grandchild.

Sabohat has worked at the hospital as a nurse for years, but her salary is not sufficient. She spent all of her savings on her son’s wedding.

Sabohat works hard in order to provide her family with the necessities. Sadly, she has become ill and needs treatment but lacks the money to buy the needed medicine.

Sabohat is requesting a loan of 3,500 TJS through Kiva’s field partner IMON International for her treatment. She needs Kiva lenders' support and mercy.

name: Rimsha
use: to buy leather petals, wax, thread and protective gloves, in order to make footballs for sale.
texts:
Rimsha lives in a remote part of Sheikhupura, Pakistan. She stitches and sells handmade footballs to earn a living. Currently, due to lack of money, she is unable to purchase the required raw materials to make footballs, including leather petals, wax, thread and protective gloves.

She therefore has applied for a loan from Kiva’s field partner, JWS Pakistan. She hopes that the loan will be useful for her business.

She is very happy and thankful to Kiva lenders.

name: Samina
use: to buy raw materials like colorful threads, needles, buttons, and artificial gems.
texts:
Samina is a working woman and mother of 5 children. She lives with her family in a village of Sheikhupura, Pakistan. She is a trained woman and utilizes her embroidery skills to produce stylish clothes for weddings and casual wear as well. Her work is very famed all around the town. Currently she is in need of financing to procure additional raw materials like colorful threads, needles, buttons, and artificial gems for her work. Therefore, she has asked for a loan from Kiva and its field partner JWS Pakistan.

Samina is very appreciative to Kiva and JWS Pakistan for their help.

name: Laiheang's Group
use: to purchase more rice seed and organic pesticide to help her rice farmland to grow well.
texts: Laiheang is 39 years old, married with seven children. They live in Battambang province. She earns a living through farming rice as her main source of income. Beside this, she is selling some kinds of vegetables to make extra income. She has been involved with her farming about 5 years and it has enabled her to save up about 5 USD per day after expenses. Because of destruction from insects and the drought, her rice did not grow well. This is the second microloan for Laiheang with VisionFund. She has used the past loan wisely and successfully to improve her family’s livelihood. Now she is leading a group of two members to seek a loan. As the group leader, she will use her entire loan to buy more rice seed and organic pesticide to improve her rice farming to grow well. She hopes to gain more yields from her rice farming than before.

name: Luis
use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, herbicides, insecticides, etc. for his corn and bean crops.
texts:
Luis is a humble person who didn’t have the opportunity to study, since his parents had few economic resources. He is married and his wife is a homemaker. His children study and live at home.

Luis has been a farmer for his entire life, which he learned from his father. He walks one kilometer to the piece of land where he plants his crops and works from 6:00 in the morning until 4:00 in the afternoon. He also works as a day laborer.

Luis will use the loan to buy seeds, fertilizers, herbicides, insecticides, etc. for his corn and bean crops.

He dreams of his family having a dignified life in which they won’t want for anything. This is why he works hard and wants to cultivate more land.

name: Grace
use: to buy farm inputs and purchase high-quality seeds, good fertilizer, and pesticides to improve crop production.
texts:
Living in a third world country where work opportunities are scarce has never been an excuse for Grace (pictured above, in her home), who has been practicing mixed farming for the past 11 years.

Grace, who lives with her husband in the Kitale area of Kenya, is blessed with four children who are her greatest motivation in life. She is a woman eager to get ahead. She perseveres because she wants to provide a better future for them. She herself was unable to go to school because of the economic situation that her family faced.

Grace has always had an affinity for farming and even nicknamed one of her cows. She is a very proud farmer who enjoys milking her dairy cows, which produce between 10-15 liters of milk a day, and this helps her to support her family. She also grows horticulture crops, but has not been making good profits because of poor farming inputs.

Grace will use this loan to buy farm inputs and purchase high-quality seeds, good fertilizer, and pesticides to improve her horticulture crop production. Modern farming requires the use of modern techniques, so using high-quality seeds will assure her of a bumper harvest and increased profit levels.

Grace is very thankful in advance for this assistance.

name: Laurentine
use: to purchase pesticides such as Actara, Plantima, Monchamp and Ridomil.
texts: Laurentine is a 53 year old woman, single and the mother of five children, one of which is a minor.  After her studies she continued to live in her village with her family and specialized in farming.  She has a 63 year old cocoa field which she inherited from her parents.  It is thanks to this plantation that she can take care of the needs of her family.  So that she has a good production it is necessary to clear the land and put on the maintenance products in time but she does not have the money to do this.  It is for this that she is requesting this loan which will allow her to buy the necessary pesticides such as Actara, Plantima, Monchamp and Ridomil.  This will increase her production and therefore her sales.  She will use a portion of this money to expand her field and the rest will help her to better take care of her family.

name: Irfana Hayat
use: to purchase sewing materials, including cloth, colorful thread, needles, buttons and lace.
texts:
Irfana Hayat is a female entrepreneur and she and her husband are struggling to bring prosperity to their family. She is 30 years old and lives in a small house with five family members. She is a skilled woman and has been making clothes as a source of income. She has about two years of experience in designing and stitching clothes.

At the moment, she lacks the funds to purchase sewing materials, including cloth, colorful thread, needles, buttons and lace, for making clothes. She therefore has requested a loan from JWS Pakistan, field partner of Kiva, to buy these supplies for her business.

She is hopeful that the loan will be productive for her business and family.

She is grateful to Kiva and JWS Pakistan for the kind help.

name: Daysi Margarita
use: to purchase a refrigerator to chill drinks for sale.
texts:
Daysi studied up to the third grade of basic education, is partnered, and her partner works as a security employee. Two grandchildren live with them and are studying.

Daysi has a store where she sells staple products. She undertook the business to help her partner with the household expenses.

She needs a loan to purchase a refrigerator to chill drinks for sale.

Daysi wants to grow her business and support her grandchildren in their studies.

name: Sumaira Rani
use: to purchase a new buffalo and good quality fodder for her animals.
texts:
Sumaira Rani is a 25-year-old woman who lives in Gujrat, Pakistan, a large agricultural city. She has been involved in a livestock business with her husband for the last few years. She and her husband take care of buffaloes and sell milk in their community to handle their family expenses.

At the moment, they are facing a problem due to low milk production as a result of a low quality of fodder. Therefore, she asked for a loan from JWS Pakistan to purchase a new buffalo and good quality fodder for their buffaloes. This will help them in raising milk production.

She is hopeful that this loan will be productive for their business. She and her husband are very thankful to Kiva and JWS Pakistan.

name: Noemí
use: to purchase parchment coffee, pay for the roasting and packaging service to sell it in Jaén.
texts:
Noemí, 29 years old, lives in the city of Jaén, Peru. Noemi lives in her parents' house and works selling toasted and ground coffee products in a variety of packaging, having aspirations to expand her business.

To do so, Noemi needs capital to purchase more parchment coffee to be able to complete the roasting, packaging and sales process. With the new inventory, she will establish her larger business in the future.

A loan to Noemi will give her the opportunity to expand her business and, given her knowledge, aspirations and entrepreneurial attitude, she is ready to get ahead. She knows that the loan is very important not only to realize her dreams, but also to offer her opportunities to grow as a businesswoman.

name: Leonzo
use: to buy fertilizers, to pay for rent on the land where he plants basic grains, and to pay for labor.
texts:
Leonzo studied through 6th grade, but also attended courses about agriculture and livestock.

Leonzo farms corn and beans and has 10 years of experience in this work. He also raises small livestock animals.

He will use the loan to buy fertilizers, to pay rent on the land where he plants basic grains, and to pay for labor.

His dream is to have a tilapia pond.

name: Nida
use: to purchase raw materials and maintenance for her business.
texts:
As a married parent of six children, Nida works hard to support her family. She has a weaving business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store. Nida is borrowing PHP 9,000 through NWTF to purchase raw materials and maintenance for her business.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Nida has been sustaining her business activities through her past 4 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

name: Luis Alonso
use: to purchase pigs to fatten them and sell them at a good price.
texts:
Luis, 33 years old, studied up to the fifth grade of basic education, is married, and his wife works selling dairy products. He has three children, of whom two are studying.

Luis has worked selling dairy products for three years. He also raises cattle and pigs. His wife is involved and helps him work.

He needs the loan to purchase pigs to fatten them and sell them at a good price.

He wants to continue working hard at his businesses so that they are more profitable and always generate income.

name: Reina Marilu
use: to purchase pigs to fatten them and then sell them.
texts:
Reina, thirty-five years old, studied up to the third grade of basic education, is partnered, and her partner is a driver. She has a baby and just the 3 of them live in the house.

Reina has worked raising pigs for ten years. She learned this from her father.

Currently, her life partner and a nephew help her in the work.

She needs the loan to purchase pigs to fatten them and then sell them.

She wants her son to become a professional in the future and, so, she will continue working to achieve it.

name: Farzana
use: to purchase an additional milking animal for her dairy business.
texts:
Farzana is 39 year old woman, she is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a farmer. She lives in a small village of Gujrat, Pakistan.



To help her husband, she takes cares of a few cows for milking. She finds this activity profitable but lacks money to bring it to some reasonable scale where it can pay back reasonable profits. Therefore she has requested a loan from JWS Pakistan, to purchase an additional milking animal.



She is very thankful to KIVA and JWS Pakistan.

name: Nosheen
use: to buy sewing supplies, such as cloth, thread, lace and buttons.
texts:
Nosheen is a married woman and lives with her husband in Gujrat, Pakistan. She is 30 years old and is a tailor by profession.

She started her tailoring business in 2012 and she continues to operate her business today. She is a skillful tailor who brings best to her clients. She has been able to support her family from this business.

One challenge she often faces is the lack of material to meet her sale orders. With this loan, she will buy materials to make clothes and position her business to offer better services.

Nosheen is very grateful to Kiva and JWS Pakistan for their help.

name: Farzana
use: to buy embroidery supplies like fabrics, thread, needles, pearls etc for her hand embroidery business.
texts:
Farzanaa, 44, is a self employed married lady and mother of 4 children. She lives with her family in Multan Pakistan. Fifteen years ago Farzana started a hand embroidery business at home. She is a trained artisan and utilizes her embroidery skills to produce stylish clothes for formal wear. Her work is very famous in her area.

Currently she is in need of financing to buy the some embroidery supplies like, threads, needles, fabrics for her work. Her husband is a mason with limited income.

Therefore, she has asked for a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan. Through this loan she can buy supplies she needs for her work. This is her 7th loan cycle. She is doing her hand embroidery work in the picture.

name: Sumathi
use: to fund a water connection to be installed at her home.
texts:
Sumathi’s family, in Tiruchirappalli district in Tamil Nadu, is one of the thousands affected by the water crisis in India. They have no water connection in their home. As they don't have a water connection at home, she treks about 1 kilometer daily to get water from the public tap. Families like Sumathi’s often enlist their children’s help to fetch the water back home, and the children end up missing school. Often, the water collected is not enough. Due to inadequate water, her family has to compromise on hygiene, and is frequently ill.

Sumathi has wanted to change this situation for a long time now. So, she has applied for a loan of INR 7,000 from Guardian, one of MIlaap's field partners. Your loan will help Sumathi get relief from carrying heavy water pots every morning. It will help her have extra hours in a day to work and earn more. With adequate water and good hygiene, her family will also enjoy better health and improved savings. Sumathi and her family will be thankful to their lenders.

name: Ibrahim
use: to purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his crop yield.
texts:
Ibrahim, a Babban Gona maize farmer from Gamagira, has been a Babban Gona farmer for one season. He has one child who aspires to be a farmer in the future.

Previously, Ibrahim and his family were able to eat only two meals a day, despite toiling for several hours on the farm. However, as a Babban Gona member, he will, as a result of this loan, be provided with higher yielding seeds that are locally adapted, and are widely accepted in his local community. He will also have the recommended pesticides and fertilizers based on the results of his field assessment. This will enable him to optimize his yield, where he can attain yields of up to 3.8 metric tons per hectare, which is two times the national average in Nigeria.

This season, Ibrahim will use the income generated from his maize sales to pay his child's school fees. Ibrahim’s greatest memory as a Babban Gona farmer was when he sent his child to a better school as a result of the loan he got in the past.

Ibrahim is confident that with Babban Gona, his future is secure and he will have many more great memories and amazing accomplishments with his family.

name: Jose Emiliano
use: to pay for a medical treatment on his leg.
texts: José Emiliano lives in a municipality near the city of Monterrey. He is 54 years old and married to Maricela. Both he and his wife work in mobile markets in their locality. He suffers from a chronic degenerative disease which has affected one of his legs, he has a severe pain for which his cannot walk. He urgently needs a medical treatment to prevent losing his limb. At the moment, he does not have the necessary income to have the treatment, so he asked for a loan to be able to have the operation as soon as possible and not lose time, since his leg is at risk.

name: Juan Enrique
use: his mother to recover her sight.
texts: Juan Enrique is 38 years old, and 15 years ago he married Maria del Carmen, with whom he had 2 boys who are currently 14 and 4. His wife takes care of the family and he has worked for 10 years in a transportation company as a mechanic. Juan Enrique is concerned about his mother's health since she was diagnosed with an eye disease which does not allow her to see. The lady needs a surgical treatment with which she would recover her sight and, so, be able to take care of herself, because since she has suffered from this disease, she needs someone's support to do all of her activities.

name: Maria Felipa
use: her mother to recover her sight.
texts: Maria Felipa lives in the city of Monterrey, she is 41 years old and 22 years ago married Roberto, with whom she formed a family with 4 children between the ages of 22 and 14. They are all currently in the process of their education. She works in the accounting department of a commercial store to economically support her husband, who works at a television company. Recently, her mother was diagnosed with a disease which does not allow her to see, a situation which worries her since she always needs someone's support to do her activities. The lady urgently needs an operation. With the requested loan, Maria Felipa will be able to pay for her mother's surgery and she will be able to see again.

name: Ignatius Nsonge
use: to buy agricultural inputs to maintain his cocoa field.
texts: Ignatius is a 29 year old young man and the father of two children.  He has lived in a local village for several years with his family where he manages a 3 hectacre cocoa field inherited from his parents.  He would like to have a better production this season.
